lines.text: Enter SICINIUS and BRUTUS

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: We hear not of him, neither need we fear him His remedies are tame i the present peace And quietness of the people, which before Were in wild hurry. Here do we make his friends Blush that the world goes well, who rather had, Though they themselves did suffer byt, behold Dissentious numbers pestering streets than see Our tradesmen with in their shops and going About their functions friendly.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: We stood tot in good time. Is this Menenius
Enter MENENIUS

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Tis he,tis he: O, he is grown most kind of late.

lines.speaker: both tribunes
lines.text: Hail sir!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Hail to you both!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Your Coriolanus Is not much missd, but with his friends: The commonwealth doth stand, and so would do, Were he more angry at it.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Alls well and might have been much better, if He could have temporized.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Where is he, hear you

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Nay, I hear nothing: his mother and his wife Hear nothing from him.
Enter three or four Citizens

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: The gods preserve you both!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Godden, our neighbours.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Godden to you all, godden to you all.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: Ourselves, our wives, and children, on our knees, Are bound to pray for you both.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Live, and thrive!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Farewell, kind neighbours: we wishd Coriolanus Had loved you as we did.

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: Now the gods keep you!

lines.speaker: both tribunes
lines.text: Farewell, farewell.
Exeunt Citizens

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: This is a happier and more comely time Than when these fellows ran about the streets, Crying confusion.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Caius Marcius was A worthy officer i the war but insolent, Oercome with pride, ambitious past all thinking, Selfloving,

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: And affecting one sole throne, Without assistance.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: I think not so.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: We should by this, to all our lamentation, If he had gone forth consul, found it so.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: The gods have well prevented it, and Rome Sits safe and still without him.
Enter an AEdile

lines.speaker: aedile
lines.text: Worthy tribunes, There is a slave, whom we have put in prison, Reports, the Volsces with two several powers Are enterd in the Roman territories, And with the deepest malice of the war Destroy what lies before em.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Tis Aufidius, Who, hearing of our Marcius banishment, Thrusts forth his horns again into the world Which were inshelld when Marcius stood for Rome, And durst not once peep out.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Come, what talk you Of Marcius

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Go see this rumourer whippd. It cannot be The Volsces dare break with us.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Cannot be! We have record that very well it can, And three examples of the like have been Within my age. But reason with the fellow, Before you punish him, where he heard this, Lest you shall chance to whip your information And beat the messenger who bids beware Of what is to be dreaded.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Tell not me: I know this cannot be.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Not possible.
Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: The nobles in great earnestness are going All to the senatehouse: some news is come That turns their countenances.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Tis this slave Go whip him, fore the peoples eyes:his raising Nothing but his report.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Yes, worthy sir, The slaves report is seconded and more, More fearful, is deliverd.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: What more fearful

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: It is spoke freely out of many mouths How probable I do not knowthat Marcius, Joind with Aufidius, leads a power gainst Rome, And vows revenge as spacious as between The youngst and oldest thing.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: This is most likely!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Raised only, that the weaker sort may wish Good Marcius home again.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: The very trick ont.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: This is unlikely: He and Aufidius can no more atone Than violentest contrariety.
Enter a second Messenger

lines.speaker: second messenger
lines.text: You are sent for to the senate: A fearful army, led by Caius Marcius Associated with Aufidius, rages Upon our territories and have already Oerborne their way, consumed with fire, and took What lay before them.
Enter COMINIUS

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: O, you have made good work!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: What news what news

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: You have holp to ravish your own daughters and To melt the city leads upon your pates, To see your wives dishonourd to your noses,

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Whats the news whats the news

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Your temples burned in their cement, and Your franchises, whereon you stood, confined Into an augers bore.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Pray now, your news You have made fair work, I fear me.Pray, your news If Marcius should be joind with Volscians,

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: If! He is their god: he leads them like a thing Made by some other deity than nature, That shapes man better and they follow him, Against us brats, with no less confidence Than boys pursuing summer butterflies, Or butchers killing flies.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: You have made good work, You and your apronmen you that stood so up much on the voice of occupation and The breath of garliceaters!

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: He will shake Your Rome about your ears.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: As Hercules Did shake down mellow fruit. You have made fair work!

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: But is this true, sir

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Ay and youll look pale Before you find it other. All the regions Do smilingly revolt and who resist Are mockd for valiant ignorance, And perish constant fools. Who ist can blame him Your enemies and his find something in him.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: We are all undone, unless The noble man have mercy.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Who shall ask it The tribunes cannot dot for shame the people Deserve such pity of him as the wolf Does of the shepherds: for his best friends, if they Should say Be good to Rome, they charged him even As those should do that had deserved his hate, And therein showd like enemies.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Tis true: If he were putting to my house the brand That should consume it, I have not the face To say Beseech you, cease. You have made fair hands, You and your crafts! you have crafted fair!

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: You have brought A trembling upon Rome, such as was never So incapable of help.

lines.speaker: both tribunes
lines.text: Say not we brought it.

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: How! Was it we we loved him but, like beasts And cowardly nobles, gave way unto your clusters, Who did hoot him out o the city.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: But I fear Theyll roar him in again. Tullus Aufidius, The second name of men, obeys his points As if he were his officer: desperation Is all the policy, strength and defence, That Rome can make against them.
Enter a troop of Citizens

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: Here come the clusters. And is Aufidius with him You are they That made the air unwholesome, when you cast Your stinking greasy caps in hooting at Coriolanus exile. Now hes coming And not a hair upon a soldiers head Which will not prove a whip: as many coxcombs As you threw caps up will he tumble down, And pay you for your voices. Tis no matter if he could burn us all into one coal, We have deserved it.

lines.speaker: citizens
lines.text: Faith, we hear fearful news.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: For mine own part, When I said, banish him, I said twas pity.

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: And so did I.

lines.speaker: third citizen
lines.text: And so did I and, to say the truth, so did very many of us: that we did, we did for the best and though we willingly consented to his banishment, yet it was against our will.

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: Ye re goodly things, you voices!

lines.speaker: menenius
lines.text: You have made Good work, you and your cry! Shalls to the Capitol

lines.speaker: cominius
lines.text: O, ay, what else
Exeunt COMINIUS and MENENIUS

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Go, masters, get you home be not dismayd: These are a side that would be glad to have This true which they so seem to fear. Go home, And show no sign of fear.

lines.speaker: first citizen
lines.text: The gods be good to us! Come, masters, lets home. I ever said we were i the wrong when we banished him.

lines.speaker: second citizen
lines.text: So did we all. But, come, lets home.
Exeunt Citizens

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: I do not like this news.

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Nor I.

lines.speaker: brutus
lines.text: Lets to the Capitol. Would half my wealth Would buy this for a lie!

lines.speaker: sicinius
lines.text: Pray, let us go.
Exeunt
